member.name: T:NMock2.Internal.CompositeType

member.name: P:NMock2.Mockery.Ordered
member.summary: Gets a disposable object and tells the mockery that the following expectations are ordered, i.e. they have to be met in the specified order. Dispose the returned value to return to previous mode.
member.value: Disposable object. When this object is disposed then the ordered expectation mode is set back to the mode it was previously to call to .

member.name: P:NMock2.Mockery.Unordered
member.summary: Gets a disposable object and tells the mockery that the following expectations are unordered, i.e. they can be met in any order. Dispose the returned value to return to previous mode.
member.value: Disposable object. When this object is disposed then the unordered expectation mode is set back to the mode it was previously to the call to .

member.name: T:NMock2.MockStyle
member.summary: Specifies how a mock object should behave when it is first created.

member.name: F:NMock2.MockStyle.Default
member.summary: Calls to members that do not have expectations set will result in ExpectationExceptions.

member.name: F:NMock2.MockStyle.Transparent
member.summary: Calls to members that do not have expectations set will pass through to the underlying implementation on the class being mocked.

member.name: F:NMock2.MockStyle.Stub
member.summary: Calls to members that do not have expectations set will be ignored. Default values are used for return values (default value of the return type, stub or empty enumerable) and the same value is returned on every call to the same member.

member.name: T:NMock2.Monitoring.CastleMockObjectFactory
member.summary: Class that creates mocks for interfaces and classes (virtual members only) using the Castle proxy generator.

member.name: T:NMock2.Monitoring.IMockObjectFactory
member.summary: Implementations of this interface are responsible for generating runtime proxies of classes and interfaces for use as mock objects.
member.remarks: Returned instances are expected to implement IMockObject and take care of intercepting calls to their public members. Intercepted calls should be forwarded on to the supplied Mockery for processing against expectations.

member.summary: Construct attribute for a given category based on a name. The name may not contain the characters ',', '+', '-' or '!'. However, this is not checked in the constructor since it would cause an error to arise at as the test was loaded without giving a clear indication of where the problem is located. The error is handled in NUnitFramework.cs by marking the test as not runnable.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.CombinatorialAttribute
member.summary: Marks a test to use a combinatorial join of any argument data provided. NUnit will create a test case for every combination of the arguments provided. This can result in a large number of test cases and so should be used judiciously. This is the default join type, so the attribute need not be used except as documentation.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.PairwiseAttribute
member.summary: Marks a test to use pairwise join of any argument data provided. NUnit will attempt too excercise every pair of argument values at least once, using as small a number of test cases as it can. With only two arguments, this is the same as a combinatorial join.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.PairwiseAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.SequentialAttribute
member.summary: Marks a test to use a sequential join of any argument data provided. NUnit will use arguements for each parameter in sequence, generating test cases up to the largest number of argument values provided and using null for any arguments for which it runs out of values. Normally, this should be used with the same number of arguments for each parameter.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.ITestCaseData
member.summary:
The ITestCaseData interface is implemented by a class that is able to return complete testcases for use by a parameterized test method.
NOTE: This interface is used in both the framework and the core, even though that results in two different types. However, sharing the source code guarantees that the various implementations will be compatible and that the core is able to reflect successfully over the framework implementations of ITestCaseData.

Constraints that need to provide additional details, such as where the error occured can override this.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpression
member.summary:
ConstraintExpression represents a compound constraint in the process of being constructed from a series of syntactic elements.
Individual elements are appended to the expression as they are reognized. Once an actual Constraint is appended, the expression returns a resolvable Constraint.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase
member.summary:
ConstraintExpressionBase is the abstract base class for the ConstraintExpression class, which represents a compound constraint in the process of being constructed from a series of syntactic elements.
NOTE: ConstraintExpressionBase is separate because the ConstraintExpression class was generated in earlier versions of NUnit. The two classes may be combined in a future version.

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase.builder
member.summary: The ConstraintBuilder holding the elements recognized so far

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase.#ctor(NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintBuilder)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class passing in a ConstraintBuilder, which may be pre-populated.
member.param: The builder.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the expression as it currently stands. This should only be used for testing, since it has the side-effect of resolving the expression.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase.Append(NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator)
member.summary: Appends an operator to the expression and returns the resulting expression itself.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase.Append(NUnit.Framework.Constraints.SelfResolvingOperator)
member.summary: Appends a self-resolving operator to the expression and returns a new ResolvableConstraintExpression.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintExpressionBase.Append(NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Constraint)
member.summary: Appends a constraint to the expression and returns that constraint, which is associated with the current state of the expression being built.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator
member.summary:
The ConstraintOperator class is used internally by a ConstraintBuilder to represent an operator that modifies or combines constraints.
Constraint operators use left and right precedence values to determine whether the top operator on the stack should be reduced before pushing a new operator.

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator.left_precedence
member.summary: The precedence value used when the operator is about to be pushed to the stack.

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator.right_precedence
member.summary: The precedence value used when the operator is on the top of the stack.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator.Reduce(NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintBuilder.ConstraintStack)
member.summary: Reduce produces a constraint from the operator and any arguments. It takes the arguments from the constraint stack and pushes the resulting constraint on it.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator.LeftContext
member.summary: The syntax element preceding this operator

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator.RightContext
member.summary: The syntax element folowing this operator

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator.LeftPrecedence
member.summary: The precedence value used when the operator is about to be pushed to the stack.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintOperator.RightPrecedence
member.summary: The precedence value used when the operator is on the top of the stack.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.PrefixOperator
member.summary: PrefixOperator takes a single constraint and modifies it's action in some way.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.PrefixOperator.Reduce(NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ConstraintBuilder.ConstraintStack)
member.summary: Reduce produces a constraint from the operator and any arguments. It takes the arguments from the constraint stack and pushes the resulting constraint on it.

member.summary: Returns the constraint created by applying this prefix to another constraint.

member.summary: Returns a constraint that will apply the argument to the members of a collection, succeeding if any of them succeed.

member.summary: Represents a constraint that succeeds if none of the members of a collection match a base constraint.

member.summary: ContainsConstraint tests a whether a string contains a substring or a collection contains an object. This allows testing whether a string is contained in a collection or as a substring of another string using the same syntax.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.EqualConstraint.Ulps
member.summary: Switches the .Within() modifier to interpret its tolerance as a distance in representable values (see remarks).
member.returns: Self.
member.remarks: Ulp stands for "unit in the last place" and describes the minimum amount a given value can change. For any integers, an ulp is 1 whole digit. For floating point values, the accuracy of which is better for smaller numbers and worse for larger numbers, an ulp depends on the size of the number. Using ulps for comparison of floating point results instead of fixed tolerances is safer because it will automatically compensate for the added inaccuracy of larger numbers.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.EqualConstraint.Percent
member.summary: Switches the .Within() modifier to interpret its tolerance as a percentage that the actual values is allowed to deviate from the expected value.
member.returns: Self

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.FloatingPointNumerics
member.summary: Helper routines for working with floating point numbers

remarks.para: The floating point comparison code is based on this excellent article: http://www.cygnus-software.com/papers/comparingfloats/comparingfloats.htm

"ULP" means Unit in the Last Place and in the context of this library refers to the distance between two adjacent floating point numbers. IEEE floating point numbers can only represent a finite subset of natural numbers, with greater accuracy for smaller numbers and lower accuracy for very large numbers.

If a comparison is allowed "2 ulps" of deviation, that means the values are allowed to deviate by up to 2 adjacent floating point values, which might be as low as 0.0000001 for small numbers or as high as 10.0 for large numbers.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.FloatingPointNumerics.AreAlmostEqualUlps(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two floating point values for equality
member.param: First floating point value to be compared
Second floating point value t be compared
Maximum number of representable floating point values that are allowed to be between the left and the right floating point values
member.returns: True if both numbers are equal or close to being equal

remarks.para: Floating point values can only represent a finite subset of natural numbers. For example, the values 2.00000000 and 2.00000024 can be stored in a float, but nothing inbetween them.

This comparison will count how many possible floating point values are between the left and the right number. If the number of possible values between both numbers is less than or equal to maxUlps, then the numbers are considered as being equal.
Implementation partially follows the code outlined here: http://www.anttirt.net/2007/08/19/proper-floating-point-comparisons/

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.FloatingPointNumerics.AreAlmostEqualUlps(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Compares two double precision floating point values for equality
member.param: First double precision floating point value to be compared
Second double precision floating point value t be compared
Maximum number of representable double precision floating point values that are allowed to be between the left and the right double precision floating point values
member.returns: True if both numbers are equal or close to being equal

remarks.para: Double precision floating point values can only represent a limited series of natural numbers. For example, the values 2.0000000000000000 and 2.0000000000000004 can be stored in a double, but nothing inbetween them.

This comparison will count how many possible double precision floating point values are between the left and the right number. If the number of possible values between both numbers is less than or equal to maxUlps, then the numbers are considered as being equal.
Implementation partially follows the code outlined here: http://www.anttirt.net/2007/08/19/proper-floating-point-comparisons/

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ResolvableConstraintExpression
member.summary:
ResolvableConstraintExpression is used to represent a compound constraint being constructed at a point where the last operator may either terminate the expression or may have additional qualifying constraints added to it.
It is used, for example, for a Property element or for an Exception element, either of which may be optionally followed by constraints that apply to the property or exception.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ToleranceMode
member.summary: Modes in which the tolerance value for a comparison can be interpreted.

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ToleranceMode.None
member.summary: The tolerance was created with a value, without specifying how the value would be used. This is used to prevent setting the mode more than once and is generally changed to Linear upon execution of the test.

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ToleranceMode.Linear
member.summary: The tolerance is used as a numeric range within which two compared values are considered to be equal.

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ToleranceMode.Percent
member.summary: Interprets the tolerance as the percentage by which the two compared values my deviate from each other.

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ToleranceMode.Ulps
member.summary: Compares two values based in their distance in representable numbers.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance
member.summary: The Tolerance class generalizes the notion of a tolerance within which an equality test succeeds. Normally, it is used with numeric types, but it can be used with any type that supports taking a difference between two objects and comparing that difference to a value.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Constructs a linear tolerance of a specdified amount

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.#ctor(System.Object,NUnit.Framework.Constraints.ToleranceMode)
member.summary: Constructs a tolerance given an amount and ToleranceMode

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.CheckLinearAndNumeric
member.summary: Tests that the current Tolerance is linear with a numeric value, throwing an exception if it is not.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Empty
member.summary: Returns an empty Tolerance object, equivalent to specifying no tolerance. In most cases, it results in an exact match but for floats and doubles a default tolerance may be used.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Zero
member.summary: Returns a zero Tolerance object, equivalent to specifying an exact match.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Mode
member.summary: Gets the ToleranceMode for the current Tolerance

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Value
member.summary: Gets the value of the current Tolerance instance.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Percent
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance, using the current amount as a percentage.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Ulps
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance, using the current amount in Ulps.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Days
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance with a TimeSpan as the amount, using the current amount as a number of days.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Hours
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance with a TimeSpan as the amount, using the current amount as a number of hours.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Minutes
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance with a TimeSpan as the amount, using the current amount as a number of minutes.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Seconds
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance with a TimeSpan as the amount, using the current amount as a number of seconds.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Milliseconds
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance with a TimeSpan as the amount, using the current amount as a number of milliseconds.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.Ticks
member.summary: Returns a new tolerance with a TimeSpan as the amount, using the current amount as a number of clock ticks.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Constraints.Tolerance.IsEmpty
member.summary: Returns true if the current tolerance is empty.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.Has
member.summary: Helper class with properties and methods that supply a number of constraints used in Asserts.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Has.Exactly(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to all members of a collection, succeeding only if a specified number of them succeed.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Has.Property(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a new PropertyConstraintExpression, which will either test for the existence of the named property on the object being tested or apply any following constraint to that property.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Has.Attribute(System.Type)
member.summary: Returns a new AttributeConstraint checking for the presence of a particular attribute on an object.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Has.Attribute``1
member.summary: Returns a new AttributeConstraint checking for the presence of a particular attribute on an object.

member.name: M:NUnit.Framework.Has.Member(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a new CollectionContainsConstraint checking for the presence of a particular object in the collection.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.No
member.summary: Returns a ConstraintExpression that negates any following constraint.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.All
member.summary: Returns a ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to all members of a collection, succeeding if all of them succeed.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.Some
member.summary: Returns a ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to all members of a collection, succeeding if at least one of them succeeds.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.None
member.summary: Returns a ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to all members of a collection, succeeding if all of them fail.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.Length
member.summary: Returns a new ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to the Length property of the object being tested.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.Count
member.summary: Returns a new ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to the Count property of the object being tested.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.Message
member.summary: Returns a new ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to the Message property of the object being tested.

member.name: P:NUnit.Framework.Has.InnerException
member.summary: Returns a new ConstraintExpression, which will apply the following constraint to the InnerException property of the object being tested.

member.name: T:NUnit.Framework.TestCaseData
member.summary:
The TestCaseData class represents a set of arguments and other parameter info to be used for a parameterized test case. It provides a number of instance modifiers for use in initializing the test case.
Note: Instance modifiers are getters that return the same instance after modifying it's state.

member.summary: The argument list to be provided to the test

member.summary: Set to true if this has an expected result

member.summary: The expected exception Type

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.TestCaseData.expectedExceptionName
member.summary: The FullName of the expected exception

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.TestCaseData.testName
member.summary: The name to be used for the test

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.TestCaseData.description
member.summary: The description of the test

member.name: F:NUnit.Framework.TestCaseData.properties
member.summary: A dictionary of properties, used to add information to tests without requiring the class to change.

member.summary: If true, indicates that the test case is to be ignored

member.name: T:Castle.Core.Logging.TraceLogger
member.summary: The TraceLogger sends all logging to the System.Diagnostics.TraceSource built into the .net framework.
member.remarks:
Logging can be configured in the system.diagnostics configuration section.
If logger doesn't find a source name with a full match it will use source names which match the namespace partially. For example you can configure from all castle components by adding a source name with the name "Castle".
If no portion of the namespace matches the source named "Default" will be used.

member.param: The name used to locate the best TraceSource. In most cases comes from the using type's fullname.

member.param: The name used to locate the best TraceSource. In most cases comes from the using type's fullname.
The default logging level at which this source should write messages. In almost all cases this default value will be overridden in the config file.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IProxyBuilder.CreateInterfaceProxyTypeWithTargetInterface(System.Type,System.Type[],Castle.DynamicProxy.ProxyGenerationOptions)
member.summary: Creates a proxy type for given and that delegates all calls to the provided interceptors and allows interceptors to switch the actual target of invocation.
member.param: The interface type to proxy.
Additional interface types to proxy.
The proxy generation options.
member.returns: The generated proxy type.
member.remarks: Implementers should return a proxy type for the specified interface(s) that delegate all executions to the specified interceptors and uses an instance of the interface as their targets (i.e. ), rather than a class. All classes should then implement interface, to allow interceptors to switch invocation target with instance of another type implementing called interface.
member.exception: Thrown when or any of is a generic type definition.

Thrown when or any of is not public. Note that to avoid this exception, you can mark offending type internal, and define pointing to Castle Dynamic Proxy assembly, in assembly containing that type, if this is appropriate.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.IAttributeDisassembler
member.summary: Provides functionality for disassembling instances of attributes to CustomAttributeBuilder form, during the process of emiting new types by Dynamic Proxy.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IAttributeDisassembler.Disassemble(System.Attribute)
member.summary: Disassembles given attribute instance back to corresponding CustomAttributeBuilder.
member.param: An instance of attribute to disassemble
member.returns: corresponding 1 to 1 to given attribute instance, or null reference.
member.remarks: Implementers should return that corresponds to given attribute instance 1 to 1, that is after calling specified constructor with specified arguments, and setting specified properties and fields with values specified we should be able to get an attribute instance identical to the one passed in . Implementer can return null if it wishes to opt out of replicating the attribute. Notice however, that for some cases, like attributes passed explicitly by the user it is illegal to return null, and doing so will result in exception.

member.returns: usually null, or (re)throws the exception

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.AttributeDisassembler.InitializeConstructorArgs(System.Type,System.Attribute,System.Reflection.ParameterInfo[])
member.summary: Here we try to match a constructor argument to its value. Since we can't get the values from the assembly, we use some heuristics to get it. a/ we first try to match all the properties on the attributes by name (case insensitive) to the argument b/ if we fail we try to match them by property type, with some smarts about convertions (i,e: can use Guid for string).

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.AttributeDisassembler.ReplaceIfBetterMatch(System.Reflection.ParameterInfo,System.Reflection.PropertyInfo,System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: We have the following rules here. Try to find a matching type, failing that, if the parameter is string, get the first property (under the assumption that we can convert it.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.INamingScope
member.summary: Represents the scope of uniquenes of names for types and their members

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.INamingScope.GetUniqueName(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a unique name based on
member.param: Name suggested by the caller
member.returns: Unique name based on .
member.remarks: Implementers should provide name as closely resembling as possible. Generally if no collision occurs it is suggested to return suggested name, otherwise append sequential suffix. Implementers must return deterministic names, that is when is called twice with the same suggested name, the same returned name should be provided each time. Non-deterministic return values, like appending random suffices will break serialization of proxies.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.INamingScope.SafeSubScope
member.summary: Returns new, disposable naming scope. It is responsibilty of the caller to make sure that no naming collision with enclosing scope, or other subscopes is possible.
member.returns: New naming scope.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.MethodFinder
member.summary: Returns the methods implemented by a type. Use this instead of Type.GetMethods() to work around a CLR issue where duplicate MethodInfos are returned by Type.GetMethods() after a token of a generic type's method was loaded.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.IChangeProxyTarget
member.summary: Exposes means to change target objects of proxies and invocations

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IChangeProxyTarget.ChangeInvocationTarget(System.Object)
member.summary: Changes the target object () of current .
member.param: The new value of target of invocation.
member.remarks: Although the method takes the actual instance must be of type assignable to , otherwise an will be thrown. Also while it's technically legal to pass null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) as , for obvious reasons Dynamic Proxy will not be able to call the intercepted method on such target. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws. Also while it's technically legal to pass proxy itself as , this would create stack overflow. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws.
member.exception: Thrown when is not assignable to the proxied type.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IChangeProxyTarget.ChangeProxyTarget(System.Object)
member.summary: Permanently changes the target object of the proxy. This does not affect target of the current invocation.
member.param: The new value of target of the proxy.
member.remarks: Although the method takes the actual instance must be of type assignable to proxy's target type, otherwise an will be thrown. Also while it's technically legal to pass null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) as , for obvious reasons Dynamic Proxy will not be able to call the intercepted method on such target. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws. Also while it's technically legal to pass proxy itself as , this would create stack overflow. In this case last interceptor in the pipeline mustn't call or a will be throws.
member.exception: Thrown when is not assignable to the proxied type.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.IInterceptorSelector
member.summary: Provides an extension point that allows proxies to choose specific interceptors on a per method basis.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.IInterceptorSelector.SelectInterceptors(System.Type,System.Reflection.MethodInfo,Castle.DynamicProxy.IInterceptor[])
member.summary: Selects the interceptors that should intercept calls to the given .
member.param: The type declaring the method to intercept.
The method that will be intercepted.
All interceptors registered with the proxy.
member.returns: An array of interceptors to invoke upon calling the .
member.remarks: This method is called only once per proxy instance, upon the first call to the . Either an empty array or null are valid return values to indicate that no interceptor should intercept calls to the method. Although it is not advised, it is legal to return other implementations than these provided in .

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.MixinData.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Object})
member.summary:
Because we need to cache the types based on the mixed in mixins, we do the following here: - Get all the mixin interfaces - Sort them by full name - Return them by position
The idea is to have reproducible behavior for the case that mixins are registered in different orders. This method is here because it is required

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope.SaveAssembly
member.summary: Saves the generated assembly with the name and directory information given when this instance was created (or with the and current directory if none was given).

remarks.para: This method stores the generated assembly in the directory passed as part of the module information specified when this instance was constructed (if any, else the current directory is used). If both a strong-named and a weak-named assembly have been generated, it will throw an exception; in this case, use the overload.
If this was created without indicating that the assembly should be saved, this method does nothing.

member.exception: Both a strong-named and a weak-named assembly have been generated.
member.returns: The path of the generated assembly file, or null if no file has been generated.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope.SaveAssembly(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Saves the specified generated assembly with the name and directory information given when this instance was created (or with the and current directory if none was given).
member.param: True if the generated assembly with a strong name should be saved (see ); false if the generated assembly without a strong name should be saved (see .

remarks.para: This method stores the specified generated assembly in the directory passed as part of the module information specified when this instance was constructed (if any, else the current directory is used).
If this was created without indicating that the assembly should be saved, this method does nothing.

member.exception: No assembly has been generated that matches the parameter.
member.returns: The path of the generated assembly file, or null if no file has been generated.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope.LoadAssemblyIntoCache(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Loads the generated types from the given assembly into this 's cache.
member.param: The assembly to load types from. This assembly must have been saved via or , or it must have the manually applied.
member.remarks: This method can be used to load previously generated and persisted proxy types from disk into this scope's type cache, eg. in order to avoid the performance hit associated with proxy generation.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.CacheMappingsAttribute
member.summary: Applied to the assemblies saved by in order to persist the cache data included in the persisted assembly.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference
member.summary: Handles the deserialization of proxies.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference.ResetScope
member.summary: Resets the used for deserialization to a new scope.
member.remarks: This is useful for test cases.

member.name: M:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference.SetScope(Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope)
member.summary: Resets the used for deserialization to a given .
member.param: The scope to be used for deserialization.
member.remarks: By default, the deserialization process uses a different scope than the rest of the application, which can lead to multiple proxies being generated for the same type. By explicitly setting the deserialization scope to the application's scope, this can be avoided.

member.name: P:Castle.DynamicProxy.Serialization.ProxyObjectReference.ModuleScope
member.summary: Gets the used for deserialization.
member.value: As has no way of automatically determining the scope used by the application (and the application might use more than one scope at the same time), uses a dedicated scope instance for deserializing proxy types. This instance can be reset and set to a specific value via and .

member.summary: For interface proxies, this will point to the on the target class

member.summary: Holds objects representing methods of class.

member.name: T:Castle.DynamicProxy.Tokens.SerializationInfoMethods
member.summary: Holds objects representing methods of class.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.Extensibility.ITestCaseProvider2

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestCaseBuilder
member.summary: Class to build ether a parameterized or a normal NUnitTestMethod. There are four cases that the builder must deal with: 1. The method needs no params and none are provided 2. The method needs params and they are provided 3. The method needs no params but they are provided in error 4. The method needs params but they are not provided This could have been done using two different builders, but it turned out to be simpler to have just one. The BuildFrom method takes a different branch depending on whether any parameters are provided, but all four cases are dealt with in lower-level methods

member.param: The test method to examine
The suite being populated
member.returns: True is the builder can use this method

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Extensibility.ITestCaseBuilder2.BuildFrom(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,NUnit.Core.Test)
member.summary: Build a TestCase from the provided MethodInfo for inclusion in the suite being constructed.
member.param: The method to be used as a test case
The test suite being populated, or null
member.returns: A TestCase or null

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestCaseBuilder.CanBuildFrom(System.Reflection.MethodInfo)
member.summary:
Determines if the method can be used to build an NUnit test test method of some kind. The method must normally be marked with an identifying attriute for this to be true. If the test config file sets AllowOldStyleTests to true, then any method beginning "test..." (case-insensitive) is treated as a test unless it is also marked as a setup or teardown method.
Note that this method does not check that the signature of the method for validity. If we did that here, any test methods with invalid signatures would be passed over in silence in the test run. Since we want such methods to be reported, the check for validity is made in BuildFrom rather than here.
member.param: A MethodInfo for the method being used as a test method
The test suite being built, to which the new test would be added
member.returns: True if the builder can create a test case from this method

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestCaseBuilder.BuildFrom(System.Reflection.MethodInfo)
member.summary: Build a Test from the provided MethodInfo. Depending on whether the method takes arguments and on the availability of test case data, this method may return a single test or a group of tests contained in a ParameterizedMethodSuite.
member.param: The MethodInfo for which a test is to be built
The test fixture being populated, or null
member.returns: A Test representing one or more method invocations

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestCaseBuilder.BuildParameterizedMethodSuite(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,NUnit.Core.Test)
member.summary: Builds a ParameterizedMetodSuite containing individual test cases for each set of parameters provided for this method.
member.param: The MethodInfo for which a test is to be built
member.returns: A ParameterizedMethodSuite populated with test cases

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestCaseBuilder.BuildSingleTestMethod(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,NUnit.Core.Test,NUnit.Core.Extensibility.ParameterSet)
member.summary: Builds a single NUnitTestMethod, either as a child of the fixture or as one of a set of test cases under a ParameterizedTestMethodSuite.
member.param: The MethodInfo from which to construct the TestMethod
The ParameterSet to be used, or null

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestCaseBuilder.CheckTestMethodSignature(NUnit.Core.TestMethod,NUnit.Core.Extensibility.ParameterSet)
member.summary:
Helper method that checks the signature of a TestMethod and any supplied parameters to determine if the test is valid.
Currently, NUnitTestMethods are required to be public, non-abstract methods, either static or instance, returning void. They may take arguments but the values must be provided or the TestMethod is not considered runnable.
Methods not meeting these criteria will be marked as non-runnable and the method will return false in that case.
member.param: The TestMethod to be checked. If it is found to be non-runnable, it will be modified.
Parameters to be used for this test, or null
member.returns: True if the method signature is valid, false if not

member.summary: Method to add test cases to the newly constructed fixture. The default implementation looks at each candidate method and tries to build a test case from it. It will only need to be overridden if some other approach, such as reading a datafile is used to generate test cases.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestFixtureBuilder.BuildTestCase(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,NUnit.Core.TestSuite)
member.summary:
Method to create a test case from a MethodInfo and add it to the fixture being built. It first checks to see if any global TestCaseBuilder addin wants to build the test case. If not, it uses the internal builder collection maintained by this fixture builder. After building the test case, it applies any decorators that have been installed.
The default implementation has no test case builders. Derived classes should add builders to the collection in their constructor.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestFixtureBuilder.IsValidFixtureType(System.Type,System.String@)
member.summary: Check that the fixture type is valid. This method ensures that the type is not abstract and that there is no more than one of each setup or teardown method and that their signatures are correct.
member.param: The type of the fixture to check
A message indicating why the fixture is invalid
member.returns: True if the fixture is valid, false if not

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Builders.NUnitTestFixtureBuilder.GetTestFixtureAttributes(System.Type)
member.summary: Get TestFixtureAttributes following a somewhat obscure set of rules to eliminate spurious duplication of fixtures. 1. If there are any attributes with args, they are the only ones returned and those without args are ignored. 2. No more than one attribute without args is ever returned.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.Event
member.summary: NUnit.Core.Event is the abstract base for all stored events. An Event is the stored representation of a call to the EventListener interface and is used to record such calls or to queue them for forwarding on another thread or at a later time.

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.Event.IsSynchronous
member.summary:
Gets a value indicating whether this event is delivered synchronously by the NUnit .
If true, and if has been used to set a WaitHandle, blocks its calling thread until the thread has delivered the event and sets the WaitHandle.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.EventQueue
member.summary: Implements a queue of work items each of which is queued as a WaitCallback.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.EventQueue.synchronousEventSent
member.summary:
WaitHandle for synchronous event delivery in .
Having just one handle for the whole implies that there may be only one producer (the test thread) for synchronous events. If there can be multiple producers for synchronous events, one would have to introduce one WaitHandle per event.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.EventQueue.SetWaitHandleForSynchronizedEvents(System.Threading.AutoResetEvent)
member.summary: Sets a handle on which to wait, when is called for an with == true.
member.param:
The wait handle on which to wait, when is called for an with == true.
The caller is responsible for disposing this wait handle.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.EventQueue.Dequeue(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes the first element from the queue and returns it (or null).
member.param: If true and the queue is empty, the calling thread is blocked until either an element is enqueued, or is called.

item.term: otherwise, if ==false or has been called

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.ProxyTestRunner
member.summary:
DelegatingTestRUnner is the abstract base for core TestRunner implementations that operate by controlling a downstream TestRunner. All calls are simply passed on to the TestRunner that is provided to the constructor.
Although the class is abstract, it has no abstract methods specified because each implementation will need to override different methods. All methods are specified using interface syntax and the derived class must explicitly implement TestRunner in order to redefine the selected methods.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.TestRunner
member.summary:
The TestRunner Interface allows client code, such as the NUnit console and gui runners, to load and run tests. This is the lowest level interface generally supported for running tests and is implemented by the RemoteTestRunner class in the NUnit core as well as by other classes running on the client side.
The Load method is used to load a suite of tests from one or more assemblies, returning a tree of TestNodes to the caller.
The CountTestCases family of methods returns the number of test cases in the loaded suite, either in its entirety or by using a filter to count a subset of tests.
The Run family of methods performs a test run synchronously, returning a TestResult or TestResult[] to the caller. If provided, an EventListener interface will be notified of significant events in the running of the tests. A filter may be used to run a subset of the tests.
BeginRun and EndRun provide a simplified form of the asynchronous invocation pattern used in many places within the .NET framework. Because the current implementation allows only one run to be in process at a time, an IAsyncResult is not used at this time.
Methods to cancel a run and to wait for a run to complete are also provided. The result of the last run may be obtained by querying the TestResult property.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.Reflect
member.summary:
Helper methods for inspecting a type by reflection.
Many of these methods take ICustomAttributeProvider as an argument to avoid duplication, even though certain attributes can only appear on specific types of members, like MethodInfo or Type.
In the case where a type is being examined for the presence of an attribute, interface or named member, the Reflect methods operate with the full name of the member being sought. This removes the necessity of the caller having a reference to the assembly that defines the item being sought and allows the NUnit core to inspect assemblies that reference an older version of the NUnit framework.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.TestExecutionContext
member.summary:
Helper class used to save and restore certain static or singleton settings in the environment that affect tests or which might be changed by the user tests.
An internal class is used to hold settings and a stack of these objects is pushed and popped as Save and Restore are called.
Static methods for each setting forward to the internal object on the top of the stack.

Gets or sets the Log writer, which is actually held by a log4net TextWriterAppender. When first set, the appender will be created and will thereafter send any log events to the writer.
In normal operation, LogWriter is set to an EventListenerTextWriter connected to the EventQueue in the test domain. The events are subsequently captured in the Gui an the output displayed in the Log tab. The application under test does not need to define any additional appenders.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.Extensibility.IAddin
member.summary: Add-ins are used to extend NUnti. All add-ins must implement the IAddin interface.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.Extensibility.IAddin.Install(NUnit.Core.Extensibility.IExtensionHost)
member.summary: When called, the add-in installs itself into the host, if possible. Because NUnit uses separate hosts for the client and test domain environments, an add-in may be invited to istall itself more than once. The add-in is responsible for checking which extension points are supported by the host that is passed to it and taking the appropriate action.
member.param: The host in which to install the add-in
member.returns: True if the add-in was installed, otehrwise false

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.Extensibility.DecoratorPriority
member.summary:
DecoratorPriority wraps constants that may be used to represent the relative priority of TestDecorators. Decorators with a lower priority are applied first so that higher priority decorators wrap them.
NOTE: This feature is subject to change.

member.summary: Priority for Decorators that must apply last

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.TestFilter
member.summary: Interface to be implemented by filters applied to tests. The filter applies when running the test, after it has been loaded, since this is the only time an ITest exists.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.ITestFilter
member.summary: Interface to be implemented by filters applied to tests. The filter applies when running the test, after it has been loaded, since this is the only time an ITest exists.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.ITestFilter.Pass(NUnit.Core.ITest)
member.summary: Determine if a particular test passes the filter criteria. Pass may examine the parents and/or descendants of a test, depending on the semantics of the particular filter
member.param: The test to which the filter is applied
member.returns: True if the test passes the filter, otherwise false

member.summary: Determine whether the test itself matches the filter criteria, without examining either parents or descendants.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.TestFilter.Empty
member.summary: Unique Empty filter.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.TestFilter.Pass(NUnit.Core.ITest)
member.summary:
Determine if a particular test passes the filter criteria. The default implementation checks the test itself, its parents and any descendants.
Derived classes may override this method or any of the Match methods to change the behavior of the filter.
member.param: The test to which the filter is applied
member.returns: True if the test passes the filter, otherwise false

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.TestFilter.Match(NUnit.Core.ITest)
member.summary: Determine whether the test itself matches the filter criteria, without examining either parents or descendants.
member.param: The test to which the filter is applied
member.returns: True if the filter matches the any parent of the test

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.TestFilter.MatchParent(NUnit.Core.ITest)
member.summary: Determine whether any ancestor of the test mateches the filter criteria

member.summary: Determine whether any descendant of the test matches the filter criteria.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.RunState
member.summary: The RunState enum indicates whether a test can be executed. When used on a TestResult it may also indicate whether the test has been executed. See individual values for restrictions on use.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.RunState.NotRunnable
member.summary: The test is not runnable.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.RunState.Runnable
member.summary: The test is runnable. This value would normally not appear on a TestResult, since it would change to Executed.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.RunState.Explicit
member.summary: The test can only be run explicitly. Would normally not appear on a TestResult, since it would change to Executed or Skipped.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.RunState.Skipped
member.summary: The test has been skipped. This value may appear on a Test when certain attributes are used to skip the test.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.RunState.Ignored
member.summary: The test has been ignored. May appear on a Test, when the IgnoreAttribute is used. Appears on a TestResult in that case or if the test is dynamically ignored.

member.summary: RuntimeFramework represents a particular version of a common language runtime implementation.

member.summary: DefaultVersion is an empty Version, used to indicate that NUnit should select the CLR version to use for the test.

member.summary: Construct from a runtime type and version
member.param: The runtime type of the framework
The version of the framework

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a string representing a RuntimeFramework. The string may be just a RuntimeType name or just a Version or a hyphentated RuntimeType-Version or a Version prefixed by 'v'.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.GetBestAvailableFramework(NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework)
member.summary: Returns the best available framework that matches a target framework. If the target framework has a build number specified, then an exact match is needed. Otherwise, the matching framework with the highest build number is used.

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.ToString
member.summary: Overridden to return the short name of the framework

member.name: M:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.Supports(NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework)
member.summary:
Returns true if this framework's supports executing under the requested target framework. The target is supported if
1. The runtime types are the same or either one is RuntimeType.Any
2. All specified (non-negative) components of the CLR version are equal.
3. The major and minor components of the current framework version are greater than or equal to the corresponding target components.
The last provision allows tests requiring .NET 2.0 to run under the 3.0 and 3.5 platforms as well.
member.param: The RuntimeFramework to be matched.
member.returns: True on match, otherwise false

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.CurrentFramework
member.summary: Static method to return a RuntimeFramework object for the framework that is currently in use.

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.AvailableFrameworks
member.summary: Gets an array of all available frameworks

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.IsAvailable
member.summary: Returns true if the current RuntimeFramework is available. In the current implementation, only Mono and Microsoft .NET are supported.
member.returns: True if it's available, false if not

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.Runtime
member.summary: The type of this runtime framework

member.summary: The framework version for this runtime framework

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.ClrVersion
member.summary: The CLR version for this runtime framework

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.AllowAnyVersion
member.summary: Return true if any CLR version may be used in matching this RuntimeFramework object.

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.RuntimeFramework.DisplayName
member.summary: Returns the Display name for this framework

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.TestID
member.summary: TestID encapsulates a unique identifier for tests. As currently implemented, this is an integer and is unique within the AppDomain. TestID is one component of a TestName. We use this object, rather than a raw int, for two reasons: (1) to hide the implementation so it may be changed later if necessary and (2) so that the id may be null in a "weak" TestName.

member.name: F:NUnit.Core.TestID.id
member.summary: The int key that distinguishes this test from all others created by the same runner.

member.summary: Parse a TestID from it's string representation

member.summary: Override of Equals method to allow comparison of TestIDs

member.summary: Override of GetHashCode for TestIDs

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.TestInfo
member.summary:
TestInfo holds common info about a test. It represents only a single test or a suite and contains no references to other tests. Since it is informational only, it can easily be passed around using .Net remoting.
TestInfo is used directly in all EventListener events and in TestResults. It contains an ID, which can be used by a runner to locate the actual test.
TestInfo also serves as the base class for TestNode, which adds hierarchical information and is used in client code to maintain a visible image of the structure of the tests.

member.summary: TestName that identifies this test

member.summary: The test description

member.summary: A list of all the categories assigned to a test

member.summary: A dictionary of properties, used to add information to tests without requiring the class to change.

It consists of a three components: the simple name of the test, an int id that is unique to a given tree of tests and an int runner id that identifies the particular runner that holds the test instance.

member.name: T:NUnit.Core.TestNode
member.summary:
TestNode represents a single test or suite in the test hierarchy. TestNode holds common info needed about a test and represents a single node - either a test or a suite - in the hierarchy of tests.
TestNode extends TestInfo, which holds all the information with the exception of the list of child classes. When constructed from a Test, TestNodes are always fully populated with child TestNodes.
Like TestInfo, TestNode is purely a data class, and is not able to execute tests.

member.summary: For a test suite, the child tests or suites Null if this is not a test suite

member.param: The TestName of the new test
An array of tests to be added as children of the new test

member.summary: Gets the parent test of the current test

member.name: P:NUnit.Core.TestNode.Tests
member.summary: Array of child tests, null if this is a test case.

member.name: T:NUnit.Util.AssemblyWatcher
member.summary: AssemblyWatcher keeps track of one or more assemblies to see if they have changed. It incorporates a delayed notification and uses a standard event to notify any interested parties about the change. The path to the assembly is provided as an argument to the event handler so that one routine can be used to handle events from multiple watchers.

member.name: T:NUnit.Util.IAssemblyWatcher

The path to the assembly is provided as an argument to the event handler so that one routine can be used to handle events from multiple watchers.

member.summary: RemoteTestAgent represents a remote agent executing in another process and communicating with NUnit by TCP. Although it is similar to a TestServer, it does not publish a Uri at which clients may connect to it. member.name: T:NUnit.Util.TestLoader
member.summary:
TestLoader handles interactions between a test runner and a client program - typically the user interface - for the purpose of loading, unloading and running tests.
It implemements the EventListener interface which is used by the test runner and repackages those events, along with others as individual events that clients may subscribe to in collaboration with a TestEventDispatcher helper object.
TestLoader is quite handy for use with a gui client because of the large number of events it supports. However, it has no dependencies on ui components and can be used independently.

member.name: T:NUnit.Gui.NUnitPresenter
member.summary:
NUnitPresenter does all file opening and closing that involves interacting with the user.
NOTE: This class originated as the static class TestLoaderUI and is slowly being converted to a true presenter. Current limitations include:
1. At this time, the presenter is created by the form and interacts with it directly, rather than through an interface.
2. Many functions, which should properly be in the presenter, remain in the form.
3. The presenter creates dialogs itself, which limits testability.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.GeneralCodeFormatter
member.summary: GeneralCodeFormatter is the front class responsible for making a basic syntax coloring of a string of text for a set of specific languages. The class encapsulates a set of algorithms where each of them addresses a specific language formatting. The use of one or another algorithm at analysing time is made through an language registering mechanism. For instance C# files are covered by CSharpCodeFormatter which has been assigned to "cs" language. If a query is made to GeneralCodeFormatter while there is no formatter that fit the given file language a default formatting is applyied through the use of the formatter registered into the property DefaultFormatter.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.IFormatterCatalog
member.summary:
The interface through which SourceCodeDisplay interacts to guess the language from a file extension.
Direct implementation is: - GeneralCodeFormatter

member.summary: Format the text using the given language formatting.
member.param: A text to be formatted
The language with which formatting the text
member.returns: A FormatterCode object

member.summary: Gets the language from the given extension.
member.param: An extension without the dot, like 'cs'
member.returns: A language name, like 'C#'

member.summary: The set of formatting algorithms.

member.returns: A non-null ICodeFormatter.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.GeneralCodeFormatter.FormatFromExtension(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: A convenient method to make the formatting of a piece of code when only the file extension is known.
member.param: The piece of code to be formatted. This parameter cannot be null.
The file extension associated to this piece of code. Ex: "cs", "cpp". This is used to pick the formatter assigned to. If no such formatter exists, the default one is picked up.
member.returns: The FormattedCode for this piece of code.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.GeneralCodeFormatter.Format(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Pick the best available formatter to format the given piece of code.
member.param: The code to be formatted. This parameter cannot be null.
The language into which code has been written. Ex: "C#", "Java". If no such formatter is available, a default formatting is applied. This parameter cannot be null.
member.returns: The formatting for this piece of code.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.Controls.ErrorPanelLayout
member.summary:
Provides the panels and layout of ErrorBrowser as shown below:
+--------------------------------------------+ | Toolbar | +--------------------------------------------+ | | | | | Content | | | | | +--------------------------------------------+
Toolbar: the control which shows buttons to alternate between the StackTraceDisplay and BrowserDisplay back and forth. The control collection of this control never changes.
Option: a free place holder to show subfeature for a specific display (e.g: StackTraceDisplay or BrowserDisplay). This control's collection changes in relation with the selected display.
Content: the place where to put the main content for the current display. This control's collection changes in regard of the selected display.

member.name: P:NUnit.UiException.Controls.ErrorPanelLayout.Toolbar

Gets or sets the control to be placed in Toolbar location. Pass null to reset Toolbar to its default state.
When setting a control, the control's hierarchy of ErrorPanelLayout is automatically updated with the passed component. Besides, the passed component is automatically positionned to the right coordinates.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.Controls.SourceCodeDisplay
member.summary:
Implements IErrorDisplay and displays data about failures and error after a test suite run. SourceCodeDisplay is a control composed of two views.
The first view displays the stack trace in an ordered list of items where each item contains the context about a specific failure (file, class method, line number).
The second view displays a CodeBox control and shows the source code of one element in this list when the localization is available.

member.summary:
Gets or sets the splitter distance expressed as a float number in the range [0 - 1]. A value of 0 collapses Control1 and makes Control2 take the whole space in the window. A value of 1 collapses Control2 and makes Control1 take the whole space in the window. A value of 0.5 makes the splitter appear in the middle of the window.
Values that don't fall in [0 - 1] are automatically clipped to this range.

member.summary: Gets or sets the "first" control to be shown. This control will appear either at the top or on the left when the orientation is respectively vertical or horizontal. If the value is not null, the control will automatically be added to the SplitterBox's hierarchy of controls. If the value is null, the former control is removed and replaced by a default and empty area.

If the value is null, the former control is removed and replaced by a default and empty area.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.FormattedCode.CodeInfo
member.summary:
A naive attempt to modelize a structure of data that manages the text to be displayed and extra data to make basic syntax coloring at rendering time, while keeping a low memory footprint.
At rendering time, CodeInfo is used to make a link between the text to be drawn and the brush color to be used during the process. So it is possible to distinguishes code, comments, keywords and strings. Currently, CodeInfo is used to split the text into a collection of couple of data, where each couple is composed of: - a string of characters - a value (called tag) that classifies this string from 0 to 3. Where 0 corresponds to 'Code', 1 to 'Keyword' and so on. These couples are named 'ClassifiedToken'. At rendering time, the process can link each of these values to a particular System.Drawing.Brush instance and display text differently.
However, keeping track of all these couples at any time could have a significative impact on memory especially for big files. Therefore, instead of storing all theses couples, CodeInfo stores just primitive information that allow to build ClassifiedToken instances on the fly.

member.name: F:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.FormattedCode.CodeInfo.Text
member.summary: Holds the entire text as a simple string.

member.name: F:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.FormattedCode.CodeInfo.IndexArray
member.summary: Array of character indexes that refers to the field "Text". Each value in this array must be interpreted as the starting index position in the string into Text.

member.name: F:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.FormattedCode.CodeInfo.TagArray
member.summary: Array of ClassificationTag values held as a byte array. There is a one-to-one correspondance with 'IndexArray'. i.e.: TagArray[0] refers to the ClassificationTag value for string sequence at IndexArray[0]. TagArray[1] refers value to IndexArray[1] and so on... Hence, the following condition: - IndexArray.Count == TagArray.Count must be verified.

member.name: F:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.FormattedCode.CodeInfo.LineArray
member.summary: This index_array is used to easily locate the start of each line of text, for instance: startingPosition[0] refers to line startingPosition 0, startingPosition[1] refers to line startingPosition 1 and so on... However, there is a small indirection in that this index_array doesn't directly hold string indexes but refers to the startingPosition of the item to be used in 'IndexArray'. Therefore, LineArray[0] gives access to the startingPosition of the IndexArray's item to be used to get the corresponding character position. Hence, line 0 starts at: IndexArray[LineArray[0]] line 1: IndexArray[LineArray[1]] and so on...

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.TokenDictionary
member.summary:
TokenDictionary is responsible for defining and identifying a set of basic strings in a given text that have a particular meaning. For instance: - Separator, (ex: "{" ";" "]" ...) - comment markers, (ex: "//" "/*" "*/") - string markers, (ex: '"' '\'') - Other -> "Text" (all other strings but the ones aboves). To achieve this, TokenDictionary firstly defines methods to register and query which strings have been registered. Secondly it defines a convenient method: TryMatch() responsible for splitting a given string in one or two parts where the first one will fall in one of the above categories. When calling TryMatch() iteratively --see Lexer--, one can tag a text into a list of tokens that might server for a semantic analysis.
TokenDictionary and Lexer are both responsible for dealing with the lexical analysis job that is the first step to make basic syntax coloring.
member.see: Front class for the lexical analysis.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.TokenDictionary.#ctor
member.summary: Build an empty instance of TokenDictionary.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.TokenDictionary.Add(System.String,NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.LexerTag)
member.summary: Build a new token and add it to the list of tokens known by TokenDictionary. Tokens must be added from the longest text value to the shortest otherwise an exception will be raised.
member.param: The token's text value. It must not be null nor empty. It must not be already defined neither. If there are tokens already defined, value's length must not be longer than the previous added token.
The token's tag value.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.TokenDictionary.Contains(System.String)
member.summary: Tests whether the given string matches a token known by this instance.
member.param: A string to be identify with a token in this instance.
member.returns: True if the string matches a token's text value in this instance, false otherwise.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.TokenDictionary.TryMatch(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Try to match in "text" + "prediction" a token previously defined with the Add() method. Since TryMatch() may return null, it should be called from a loop that scans iteratively all characters of an input text.
TryMatch() can put the caller in the two following situations: 1) if parameters "text"+"prediction" don't hold any token, null will be returned. In this case caller is expected to append to "text" one character more and to shift "prediction" by one character ahead before calling TryMatch() again. 2) if parameters "text"+"prediction" look like [data]TOKEN --where [data] is any other string but the ones in tokens-- TryMatch() will return an instance of LexToken which LexToken.Text and LexToken.Tag properties will be setup with identified data. In this case caller is expected to shift its reading position by the lenght of text put in LexToken.Text. Besides "text" parameter should reset its length to 1 again.
member.param: At the very beginning, text should be of size 1 and set up with the first character from the input text. Each time TryMatch() return null, the following character from the input text should be appended to "text". Once a token is returned, this parameter should reset its size to 1 and be filled with the character coming just after the identified string. This parameter cannot be null.

This parameter represents a constant sized string that goes just before the data in "text". If the caller reach the end of the text and there are not enough character to fill "prediction" completely this parameter can be filled with remaining character and eventually becoming empty. The size of this string should be equal to the lenght of the longest token defined in this instance of TokenDictionary. This parameter cannot be null.
member.returns: The first identifiable LexToken in "text"+"prediction". Returns may be null.
member.see: To have a look on the loop implementation..

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.TokenDictionary.PopulateTokenStartingWith(NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.LexToken,System.Collections.Generic.List{NUnit.UiException.CodeFormatters.LexToken})

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.FunctionParser
member.summary: This class is responsible for locating and initializing RawError.Function property with the function name as it is mentioned in the stack trace line. To work correclty, the class makes some assumptions concerning the function format. A function name is made of two parts: [name][args] where [name] refers to a string of characters that doesn't contain ' ' and [args] refers to a string delimited by '(' and ')'.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.FunctionParser.TryParse(NUnit.UiException.StackTraceParser,NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalyzers.RawError)
member.summary: Try to match a function name by reading RawError.Input. If a match is found, the method outputs the result into RawError.Function and returns true.
member.param: An instance of parser, this parameter cannot be null.
An instance of RawError. This parameter cannot be null.
member.returns: True if a match occurs, false otherwise.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.LineNumberParser
member.summary: LineNumberParser tries to match a line number information given in a stack trace line. It relies on the following assumptions: - the line number is located after the last ':' character, - the line number is not part of a word, - there cannot be more than one line number after the last ':' - the line number must be > 0

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.LineNumberParser.TryParse(NUnit.UiException.StackTraceParser,NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalyzers.RawError)
member.summary: Reads args.Input and try to locate a line number information. If a match occurs the method fills args.Line with the identified integer.
member.param: The StackTraceParser instance. The parameter cannot be null.
The RawError instance from where read and write Input and Line properties. The parameter cannot be null.
member.returns: True if a match occurs, false otherwise.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.PathCompositeParser
member.summary: Encapsulates a set of algorithms that try to match and locate a path value coming from a raw stack trace line.

member.summary: Build a new instance of PathParser.

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.PathCompositeParser.TryParse(NUnit.UiException.StackTraceParser,NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalyzers.RawError)
member.summary: Try to read from a stack trace line a path value given either under the form of a Windows path or a UNIX path. If a match occurs the method fills args.Function with the identified data.
member.param: The instance of StackTraceParser, this parameter cannot be null.
The instance of RawError from where read and write RawError.Input and RawError.Function properties. This parameter cannot be null.
member.returns: True if a match occurs, false otherwise.

member.summary: Gives access to the IErrorParser instance that handles Unix like path values.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.UnixPathParser
member.summary: This class is responsible for extracting a Unix like path value from a line of the given stack trace. This class bases its work on the following assumptions: - paths are supposed to be absolute, - paths are supposed to be made of two parts: [/][path] Where [/] refers to the Unix mount point and [path] a non empty string of characters that extends to the trailing ':' (as given in stack trace).

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.UnixPathParser.TryParse(NUnit.UiException.StackTraceParser,NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalyzers.RawError)
member.summary: Locates and fills RawError.Path property with the first Unix path values found from RawError.Input property.
member.param: The stack trace parser. This parameter must not be null.
The RawError from which retrieving and filling Input and Path properties. This parameter cannot not be null.
member.returns: True if a match occured, false otherwise.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.WindowsPathParser
member.summary: This class is responsible for extracting a Windows like path value from a line of the given stack trace. This class bases its work on the following assumptions: - paths are supposed to be absolute, - paths are supposed to be made of two parts: [drive][path] Where [drive] refers to a sequence like: "C:\\" and [path] a non empty string of characters that extends to the trailing ':' (as given in stack trace).

member.name: M:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalysers.WindowsPathParser.TryParse(NUnit.UiException.StackTraceParser,NUnit.UiException.StackTraceAnalyzers.RawError)
member.summary: Locates and fills RawError.Path property with the first Windows path values found from RawError.Input property.
member.param: The stack trace parser. This parameter must not be null.
The RawError from which retrieving and filling Input and Path properties. This parameter cannot not be null.
member.returns: True if a match occured, false otherwise.

member.name: T:NUnit.UiException.StackTraceParser
member.summary: StackTraceParser is the entry class for analyzing and converting a stack trace - as given by .NET - into a manageable and ordered set of ErrorItem instances. StackTraceParser contains internaly a set of autonom, independent and interchangeable algorithms that makes the analysis of the stack robust and opened to changes. Its architecture is designed to abstract callers from secondary details such as the type of culture or file system that can both affect the format of the final stack as provided by .NET. In the future, this class could easily be extended by exposing a kind of register() method that would allow client code to append new algorithms of analysis in its internal list.

member.param: A string value that should contain a .Net stack trace.

member.name: T:CP.Windows.Forms.ExpandingTextBox

A special type of textbox which can display a tooltip-like window to show the full extent of any text which doesn't fit. The window may be placed directly over the label or immediately beneath it and will expand to fit in a horizontal, vertical or both directions as needed.
